content.body: Recently added to the HTML spec, "A new {{CustomElementRegistry}} object." (x2) is odd. Shouldn't they be "a new CustomElementRegistry object"?
annevk: thoughts on https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/pull/1820 appreciated.
jmdyck: ouch. Will fix.
That's what you get for editing DOM and HTML at the same time.
Domenic: oh, I think I gave a review of what you already surmised, oops
content.formatted_body: Domenic: oh, I think I gave a review of what you already surmised, oops

content.body: thinks a bit more
Maybe I just need to audit all uses...
A lot of cases seem to be misusing request's window when they should be using its client
A lot of others are just setting window to no-window
The latter is fine. The former I agree with is likely wrong. But I do think we want something like a Window object here, not just an abstract reference to a tab.
When we present something to the end user it's important that the end user can attribute it to a particular origin.
Hmm, curious to learn why
Well I see you commented on GitHub
End users need to be able to blame the address bar. If we end up showing a dialog for an unrelated website, we've done it wrong.
The navigation case seems tricky though because do we really want to associate browser UI navigation with the previous `Window` object that just so happens to be in this tab?
content.formatted_body: The navigation case seems tricky though because do we really want to associate browser UI navigation with the previous Window object that just so happens to be in this tab?

content.body: Yeah that is a tricky case and I doubt we'd want to use the previous Window. It probably needs to show a blank page or something beneath the authentication dialog?
I mean in practice it'll show the previous page beneath it in the actual UI. But it might influence the contents of any dialogs, in theory.
Are you sure that's what happens for this case? That would seem quite confusing.
I'm about 90% sure, will try to reproduce
Wooooah you're right. Go to https://example.com, then open https://labs.w0s.jp/http/authorization/basic/ .
OK so... maybe introduce a third value, "browser-ui-navigation" or something? And then let that show WWW-Authenticate dialogs, etc., with a special callout to blank out the page or similar?
Yeah, something in that direction seems reasonable. Though it might also be subject to a same-origin check I suppose.
Right, testing does show that to be the case, OK. Will give it a shot.
